note.p: This document is a letter from Captain William B. Anderson (1822-1897), to his wife, Mary Louisa (Fischgens) Anderson. He wrote this from Cincinnati, on September 1st, 1862. It is one page long, with no other notes or enclosures. It is written on lined notebook paper, folded in half lengthwise and into thirds after that. There is no surviving envelope that goes with it, and it is approximately eight inches by ten inches in size. There is a printer's mark in the upper-left hand corner, in the shape of a shield surrounded by greenery, with a crown on top. The left edge of the paper is slightly ragged and worn, as if it had been torn from a composition book or a pad of paper bound on the left.

projectDesc.p: This very short letter, written by William B. Anderson to his wife, Mary Louisa, in September of 1862, is the 1862 edition of what we do on cell phones or by e-mail every day: discussing his day to day life, even when it seems mundane. It addresses his happiness at the way business is going at the time of the letter, his concern at the way matters at home are going, and the various challenges that a riverboat captain on the Ohio River in the Civil War era might face. His spelling is less than perfect, and his grammar might leave much to be desired—much like the email or phone conversations that we might have with our distant relatives in 2006.

This letter resembles the other letters from William to Louisa that are in the collection in The Ohio State University Rare Books and Manuscripts Library. It was written in Cincinnati, one of the many thriving ports that Anderson visited on the Ohio River, as were all but two of the letters in the collection. The issues in the letter, which included family life, business, and day to day discussion, are common themes throughout the collection. His poor grammar and spelling are also regular occurrences, and in some of the letters, Anderson frequently apologizes for the mistakes that occur because of the speed with which he had to write. These are some of the threads that tie the entire collection together.

However, this letter stands out from the others for a variety of reasons. In many of the other letters in the collection, Anderson's cross–outs and spelling mistakes are numerous. In this particular letter, there are only a few glaring mistakes: the word "chute" is spelled "Shute" and the word "business" has an extra 's'. In addition, in this particular letter, business is actually going quite well, whereas in most of the letters, it is not. Anderson even references the bad business in the last few lines of the letter.

Though this letter is an example of correspondence in an earlier time, it is interesting to note the similarities to our correspondence today. Obviously, there was not instant communication in 1862, but the topics of conversation were not so different from our own. Hopefully, this collection will be a link to the past, but also, a reminder that things might not have changed so very much, after all.

editorialDecl.p: In this collection, the Anderson letters are transcribed diplomatically, meaning that the words on the page are what is described. Abbreivations, misspellings, capitalization, punctuation, and all other elements found in these letters appear exactly as they do in the original collection. All names and places are encoded with a "value" tag, and all dates appear in a standard format.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. bibl.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Mary Louisa Anderson, on September 1st, 1862 from Cincinnati, Ohio

div1.p: In this document, William B. Anderson lists his itinerary and the business conducted at each port of call. He brings oats to Gallipolis, Ohio; retrieves wheat from Graham's Station, West Virginia, and brings it to Blennerhasset's Island, West Virginia. During his travels, it was necessary to build a chute and hire oxen in order to bring the wheat to Blennerhasset's Island. In the latter part of the letter, Anderson discusses his hope to sell his boat, as business is stopped now that the previous travels are finished. He finishes by sending his love to his wife and children.
Previous letter [not yet edited] Next letter 17 September 1862

Yours came safe to hand & I was
glad to hear from you though sorry to hear that
all was not well but hope that before this all are
fully recoved. I have been quite unwell since I left
here but have got better so took a load of Oats
for the Government up to Gallipolis2 and from there
we went up to take our Wheat that we left
at Grahams Station3 and and succeeded in getting
up as far as the foot of Blennerhassets Island4
and there we dug a Shute wide and deep enough
to draw a flat drawing but 13 inches over and at
3 lads got our wheat over and then hired a man
and a team of oxen to haul the flat of and left
the 2nd clerk there to attend to it we arrived here
this morning and will leave at noon for Maysville5 with a
load of Mules and then I don’t know what we will
do though on our return I will write again I am
quite busy now but will probably have more time
to write about when I come back again I
may sell the boat I will try to any how
I hope to be home soon and will most
likely lay up if I don’t sell things are very
checkered and all bussiness is stopped give my
love to the children and take care of them
and you
div1.closer:
Your affectionate husband
PS. Write as before
WB Anderson

div1.head: Notes
div1.note:
1. Mary Louisa Fischgens married William B. Anderson on September 15th, 1853.
The Anderson Family, 1

2. Gallipolis, Ohio is located in Gallia county, in the southeastern tip of Ohio. It is a port city on the Ohio River.
"Gallipolis, Ohio." Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia.

3. Graham's Station, West Virgina is now known as Bluefield, West Virigina. It was a port city on the Ohio River.
"Bluefield, WV." Wikipedia, the free enclyclopedia.

4. Blennerhasset's Island, West Virginia is an island in the Ohio River, and was originally a slave plantation.
"Blennerhasset Island Historical State Park."

5. Maysville, Kentucky is located on the Ohio River, in the northeast corner of the state.
"Maysville, KY." Wikipedia, the free online encyclopedia."
